greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the least number of prime factors (counted with multiplicity) of any integer with n divisors.
comment: n*a(n) is the number of complex multiplications needed for the fast Fourier transform of n numbers, writing n = r1 * r2 where r1 is a prime.
This sequence with offset 1,3 and a(1) = 0 is completely additive with a(p^e) = e*(p-1) for prime p and e >= 0. - _Werner Schulte_, Feb 23 2019
reference: H. S. Wilf, Algorithms and complexity, Internet Edition, Summer, 1994, p. 56.
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..1000
K. V. Lever, Problem 89-11: The complexity of the standard form of an integer, SIAM Rev. 31 (3) (1989) 493-498.
H. S. Wilf, Algorithms and complexity, Internet Edition, 1994, p. 56.
formula: a(n) = Sum ( e_i * (p_i - 1) ) where n = Product ( p_i^e_i ) is the canonical factorization of n.
a(n) = row sums of A138618 - row products of A138618. [_Mats Granvik_, May 23 2013]
a(n) = A001414(n) - A001222(n). - _David James Sycamore_, Jul 17 2019
mathematica: Table[Total[(First /@ FactorInteger[n] - 1) Last /@ FactorInteger[n]], {n, 2, 100}] (* _Danny Marmer_, Nov 13 2014 - adapted to the offset by _Vincenzo Librandi_, Nov 13 2014 *)
xref: Same as A087656 apart from offset.
Cf. A001414, A001222. - _David James Sycamore_, Jul 17 2019
